title.narrative: Piloting CMAM Surge Approach- A Step Towards Building Health System Preparedness

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The CMAM Surge approach aims to build more resilient health systems by helping government health teams better anticipate, plan for and respond to seasonal surges in caseloads of acute malnutrition and other childhood illnesses. These surges often overwhelm capacity of local health systems, even when surges do not qualify as full blown emergency, requiring external humanitarian response. Many of these silent, local emergencies go undetected and stretch health systems to near breaking point. This leads to poor quality service in the lead up to and during nutrition crises-just when support is needed the most. Traditional emergency response often comes late and is not catered to the local needs. These shortcomings compromise effectiveness and efficiency of the response although nutrition emergencies are fairly predictable because they are linked to seasonal factors such as drought, malaria, ARI, diarrhea, etc. The CMAM Surge approach was developed by Concern Worldwide to address these issues and bring a DRR lens to health system strengthening by offering an alternative to start-stop humanitarian nutrition response in vulnerable contexts. The Surge approach was piloted and refined in Kenya and Uganda and since then, both national governments have endorsed the approach for scale up. The proposed CMAM surge Action will be implemented in Umerkot, a drought affected area with high caseload of acute malnutrition and classified as Phase 4, a critical situation requiring urgent attention, in the 2017 IPC Acute Malnutrition Analysis.Although a CMAM programme is operational in the area, it is unable to manage seasonal surges in caseloads. The proposed CMAM Surge approach will therefore strengthen the capacity of government health systems to better anticipate, plan for and manage seasonal surges in caseloads of malnutrition without undermining the capacity of the health system. [MR-2] inputs on MR-2 attached as annex MR-2 section 1.3.
